field_edited_text.value:
The Pros and Cons of Expressways

u 1
j
'B'BR'EB'B!
‘ t | ]



complete solution.

Expressways Can Create Blight

While expressways can reduce materially the blighting effect of
through traffic on surface streets, expressways themselves can be blighting
agents if they are not properly located and designed. This can happen
in several ways:

1. Physical Barriers: An expressway can act as a physical barrier
making more difficult communication and circulation between land
on one side and land on the other. The extent to which this bar-
rier exists depends to a considerable degree upon the type of
construction. A depressed expressway will not be an important
barrier if all intersecting streets are bridged over the expressway;
to the extent that some previously existing streets are not bridged
the degree of separation will be increased. Expressways elevated
on a structure generally allow free access beneath the structure
and thus represent no physical barrier, although the structure
itself may act as a psychological barrier. Expressways elevated
on an embankment or running along the surface generally permit
the fewest crossings and thus act as the greatest barriers.

The importance of the separating effect of an expressway depends
upon the land use on either side. It is generally of little or no
importance if the expressway runs along some natural feature
which itself acts as a barrier—down a ravine, along a waterfront,
etc. It is normally not of great importance (and sometimes help-
ful) if the land use on one side differs from the land use on the
other—e.g., along the dividing line between residential and indus-
trial development. The same conclusion generally applies if the
expressway serves to divide well-established residential neighbor-

25

hoods. On the other hand, the barrier formed by an expressway
can be definitely harmful when the expressway passes through
the middle of an established neighborhood, and the higher the
quality of the neighborhood the more harmful the effect is apt
to be. An expressway can also be detrimental when it serves to
separate areas which should be in close proximity for economic or
business reasons. An expressway embankment with few crossings
passing through the middle of a single industrial holding would
be an extreme example.

. Noise: The noise created by an expressway can have an adverse

effect on surrounding properties, although it is usually less bother-
some than one would think considering the volume and speed of
the traffic involved. The noise tends to be steady and this type of
noise is usually less objectionable than the alternate roars and
silences of passing rush hour slugs of traffic along important one-
way streets. The worst noise associated with an expressway is
created by heavy trucks negotiating up-grades on access ramps.
Ordinarily the noise factor is a problem only with respect to
residential structures facing elevated or on-grade expressways.
For other types of structures the noise will be no more harmful
(and in most cases less troublesome) than the general level of
traffic noise now prevailing on major surface streets. The nature
of construction for a depressed expressway generally results in
the expressway lanes being some distance from the nearest build-
ings and this plus the difference in grades usually minimizes the
noise problem. For this and other reasons depressed expressways
are greatly to be preferred through residential areas.

A difficult noise problem can be created by the lower deck of a
double-decked elevated structure in close proximity to residential
